title: Even The Best Camera Won't Work Without Better Software & Hardcore Hardware
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2018
text: I've had several GoPros (a half dozen over the years), and I'm a early-adopter of consumer 360 video. This camera was specifically purchased to replace my Samsung Gear 360 which easily produces 360 video, but has sub-par video quality. Given that the GoPro Omni runs about $1,400, the GoPro Fusion is a steal at less than half that cost.

title: So far impressed, but the complete lack of easily found documentation makes it difficult for the uninspired.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2018
text: This GoPro Fusion is a beast. The housing is 2-3 times larger than even the largest other GoPro models, the battery is about twice as large, and the camera requires two micro-SD cards to even function (one card for the forward-facing lens, and one card for the rear-facing lens). The files are also HUGE (more on that later). Thankfully though, even though the camera is physically much larger than any other GoPro before it, it still uses the same versatile mounts.

title: BEWARE, DO NOT BUY!
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2019
text: The GoPro Fusion looks and feels like a camera that has potential, but GoPro has got to get better file compression and make the app/software integration better. I was totally unable to stitch and render any 360 video on my phone because of the massive space requirements, so I downloaded the Windows 10 desktop software. When I then tried to stitch and render a video of approximately 1.5 minutes in length, I could see that the resulting file would take hours to render (not including the time it'd take to then upload it later to YouTube) and would be nearly six gigabytes in size. To be clear, that's one huge video. This estimated size I was given for a 1.5 minute video with the GoPro Fusion was the same as the average rip of a 2-hour Blu-Ray video.

title: Awesome 5.2K Spherical Videos; not so awesome software.
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2018
text: The sheer size of the files that the GoPro Fusion produces and the fact that the computer horsepower required to stitch and render them is quite significant makes this a no-go for me. Unless you're going to stick to filming videos of only a few seconds in length, any videos that are a few minutes in length will require hours of your time. That's just too heavy of a commitment for me to have the latest/greatest in "wow" factor videos. I'd rather invest the time and money in full-frame video from a mirrorless camera or using another GoPro action cam.

title: Not worth the money!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2018
text: To be clear, this camera has awesome potential and the image quality is outstanding (it's an absolute game changer). But the technology is so cutting edge that I don't see this being a practical camera unless you're a pro or pro-am with hardcore hardware and a lot of time on your hands.

title: Doesn't work with its own softwarep- makes it extremely difficult to use
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2018
text: I will update this review in a few days, there are a couple of statements I need to state.  First, the documentation is completely void from this camera.  If you don't have the appetite for "figuring it out" then don't bother.  GoPro, you can do better in sending a simple 10 page quick start guide, I know all the materials are in the video but...  I first did not know where the buttons were, I finally figured that out, then by accident paired with the phone and from there things became easier.  The software at first glance looks fine, of course I will figure out more once I start using it more heavily.

title: Best 360 camera for under $1000
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2018
text: Only from reading, I understand that folks have had issues with the software.  GoPro, you have an edge right now, don't blow it because of crappy software, if you cant do it yourself partner with someone, but the software is probably more important than the hardware in making compelling 360 videos and 2D videos from 3D source.  Don't set the bar and then let others cross it because of inferior software.  Bite the bullet and just fix it.

title: Looks Great, shoots in night and day
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2018

I will try to put together a quick guide over the next couple of weeks and post it, but Amazon, you stand to make lots of sales if you can show how the 80% of folks can get what they need from this camera by understanding 20% of its capabilities.

title: Understand the workflow and fall in love with this product
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2019
text: I'll start by saying that the Fusion delivers really clean 5.2 K spherical video and it's really fun to shoot with. Using the free Fusion Studio app on Mac (haven't tried the Windows version), you can render out very nice video images with gimbal-like stabilization. It's the best stabilization I've ever seen on a 360 camera. Even with walking and micro vibrations, the hardware/software combination yields buttery-smooth movement. Using the Fusion is like having 2 GoPro Heros strapped back to back, and the Fusion Studio software allows you to do what GoPro calls "overcapture" which is to say you can do 16:9 HD or 4:3 cutouts from any part of the 360 sphere. But to be clear, you don't need Fusion Studio to do 16:9 cutouts. This can easily be done in Final Cut Pro X or Premiere by putting the equirectangular clips into a standard 1080 timeline, then adjusting the orientation of the sphere. The footage cuts perfectly into a project with other GoPro aquired1080 footage. Now the not-so-good news. The app itself is really, really slow to stitch. I have an iMac Pro 8 Core and 12 minutes of video took 8 hours to render!! Fortunately, I use another Pro stitching software, and it only took 1 hour for the same footage. So GoPro has to improve how the app is using the CPU. Assuming your clips are relatively short and you're patient, (let the clips render overnight) the camera is truly the best 360 camera I've used (and I've used a lot of them).

title: Great Price!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2020
text: Short and sweet.  How can a camera of this price, category, and technology omit the MOST BASIC OF ALL CAMERA FUNCTIONS?  I can think of no camera released in the past 10yrs that costs 1/10th of this one that blows off the implementation of Exposure and White Balance Control.  Literally, you CANNOT lock your exposure or WB and cannot choose shutter speeds.  Sure..AUTO EVERYTHING with a simple +/- EV control can work fine in easy environments... but go in and out of shadows, mixed light...shoot time lapse, etc and watch that exposure and white balance bounce all over the place.  I honestly expected more from GoPro and it never even crossed my mind that these BASIC features would be excluded.  For me, I may just have to return it as I cannot accept these limitations no matter how great it looks in bright even sunlight.  PLEASE FIX THIS and I may repurchase.  Interesting that there are so many comments marked "Helpful" when they are "rah rah"...but there are some big-time shortcomings that people should consider and not be swayed exclusively by only positive reviews.  One additional - Be sure you don't mind a 10x-15x to 1 rendering ratio on even the latest of computers.  1min of footage will take 10-15min to render.  For reference, my latest top of line Macbook Pro it's 10 to 1.

title: Fantastic 360 camera, with some glaring flaws
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2019
text: I have forty-two 360 cameras and panoheads, and as of March 2018, Fusion has the highest video quality for consumer 360 cameras under $1,000.  Even though its nominal resolution is lower than that of the Virb 360 or Yi 360 VR, Fusion has noticeably more detail than either of them or any other consumer 360 camera.  Its video quality is so high that it is almost as good as my $3,500 Insta360 Pro in 8K mode.  Fusion's stabilization is also excellent, although the stabilization is a bit below that of the Rylo.  Its photos are pretty good as well, again with excellent dynamic range.

title: Camera good, software bad
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2018
text: Potentially great hardware that will never be great because gopro doesn't care. The problem is the software, it's terrible. And since their software is the gatekeeper this means your footage is useless. Specifically the desktop app crashes, doesn't get updated often enough, and is horrendously slow. Worse yet the Android software blocks use unless you have a compatible phone. So after waiting months for it to work on my OP5, I get an OP6, and I'm out in the cold again.

title: Good camera, lousy apps
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2018
text: This is a great camera.  The video it takes looks amazing, better than anything else I've seen in the price range.  The pictures are great too.  It really adds an extra level to your vacation pics and vids when you can look around 360 degrees. I looked at a few alternatives, and the Fusion just had the best, natural looking videos, with the best color.  The app and desktop software is where it really falls off.  The app isn't fully functional on Samsung phones for some reason (only the world's largest phone manufacturer, that's all). You can't share videos from the phone.  The desktop software requires a really high-end CPU and a decent video card, and it's still very slow to render.  While on vacation I was able to render 360 pics on a cousins cheap laptop, but had to wait until I got home to render 360 video.

title: great quality device but 100% worthless
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2019
text: Another issue is with the desktop app crashing all the time.  I have a high-end computer, i7-6700k 24GB RAM RTX 2080, and whenever I would render 5.2k or 5.6k videos, the app would start to consume all of my memory and then crash.  I read that turning-off 360 audio could fix it, but I want 360 audio, so I found this workaround.  In Windows 10, go to task manager, and the 'Details' tab.  Find the Fusion Studio app, right-click, select 'Set Affinity'.  You need to limit the number of corse the Fusion Studio app has access to.  You can play around with it to find the right mix, but I've found limiting it to Core 1, 2, and 3 works every time, but makes the rendering process even slower!

title: Amazing!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2018
text: Watching video is another issue.  My 5k video uploaded to Youtube seems to work fine everywhere.  I have an Oculus GO which couldn't handle the 5k video from the Fusion (very slow and choppy). The GO works with 4k exported video, but it looses some detail. My hi-res pictures worked fine on everything.

title: STAY AWAY FROM THE FUSION!!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2019
text: The GoPro plus service works for this camera, but unfortunately they won't let you upload video to the cloud, which kills it IMO.  So basically all you get is the camera replacement service, for $5/month, plus you have to pay a deductible should you need a replacement.  Plus 50% off accessories, but it seems to me like the Gopro website has accessories twice the price as amazon anyways, so it's a wash.  Kind of a waste in my opinion, get the damage protection plan instead from the retailer.

title: Amazing Footage.  Everything Pales to a 360.
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2019
text: I am GoPro obsessed.  I have 2 Sessions, Heros 4,6,7 (got to recycle the older versions) and now the Fusion.  Granted, I have never owned a 360 camera before, but I have been very satisfied with the GP Fusion.  I don't do too many fancy things with it.  We are an all Mac household so I stitch and edit videos through my desktop.  It runs more slowly on smaller devices but runs very well on my higher processor desktop.  Everything else pales in comparison to the 360 if you take into consideration the 3D nature of the videos.  The video quality will catch up eventually, given the new software in beta.  I am very much looking forward to these improvements and remain a hardcore avid customer/fan of GoPro.  Now if only there's a way to stick a fusion to your body whilst doing active extreme sports, that would be fantastic. ;)

date: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2019
text: While the GoPro Fusion is a very easy camera to hold, record and operate the ability to download and convert these files to usable videos is labor intensive.  The software that pairs with the camera is "okay" at best and the conversion process is very SLOW...even on a high-powered computer.  I would also like to note that the highest quality conversions in 5k crash my computer.  I'm running an i7-6700k 4 GHz with 32 GBs of Ram and a GeoForce GTX 1080.  This should not be a problem, but it is.  Still happy with the purchase, frustrated with its downfalls.

title: I lost $15,000 because of this camera
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2018
text: I bought this camera for a 360 video shoot in Northern Sweden this weekend. The two photographers flew from the US and 5 minutes after starting to shoot, the camera overheated. They only had 24 hours to shoot and because of their remote location, could not get a new camera. They are now heading home with no footage yet - it cost me over $15,000 for their time and expenses. I will never buy another GoPro product ever again and will do everything I can to warn others to not trust their equipment. I wonder how many other people and companies have lost money and memories because GoPro fails to make a reliable product.
